stages.heading: Motion is Everywhere
stages.content: In everyday life, we see objects at rest and in motion. Birds fly, cars move, and blood flows. Even atoms, planets, and stars are in motion.

stages.heading: Perception of Motion
stages.content: We often perceive an object to be in motion when its position changes with time. Sometimes motion is inferred indirectly, like observing dust movement to know the wind is blowing.

stages.heading: Relative Motion
stages.content: An object may appear moving to one person and stationary to another. For example, roadside trees appear to move backwards to passengers in a moving bus, but are stationary to a person on the road.

stages.heading: Reference Point
stages.content: To describe the location of an object, we specify a reference point called the origin. For example, if a school is 2 km north of the railway station, the station is the reference point.

stages.heading: Distance
stages.content: The total path length covered by an object is the distance. It has only magnitude (numerical value) and no direction.

stages.heading: Displacement
stages.content: The shortest distance measured from the initial to the final position of an object is known as displacement. It has both magnitude and direction.

stages.heading: Difference
stages.content: The magnitude of displacement can be zero (if the object returns to the start), but the distance covered will not be zero.

stages.heading: Uniform Motion
stages.content: If an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time, it is said to be in uniform motion.

stages.heading: Non-Uniform Motion
stages.content: If an object covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time, it is in non-uniform motion. Example: A car moving on a crowded street.

stages.heading: Speed
stages.content: The distance travelled by an object in unit time is called speed. The SI unit is metre per second (m/s).

stages.heading: Average Speed
stages.content: Since speed is often not constant, we use average speed. Average speed = Total distance travelled / Total time taken.

stages.heading: Definition
stages.content: Velocity is the speed of an object moving in a definite direction. It specifies both magnitude and direction.

stages.heading: Changing Velocity
stages.content: Velocity can change by changing the object's speed, direction of motion, or both.

stages.heading: Average Velocity
stages.content: If velocity changes at a uniform rate, Average velocity = (Initial velocity + Final velocity) / 2.

topics.title: Rate of Change of Velocity: Acceleration

stages.heading: Definition
stages.content: Acceleration is the measure of the change in the velocity of an object per unit time. Acceleration = (Change in velocity) / (Time taken).

stages.heading: Formula
stages.content: If velocity changes from u (initial) to v (final) in time t, then acceleration a = (v - u) / t. The SI unit is m/s².

stages.heading: Uniform Acceleration
stages.content: If velocity changes by equal amounts in equal time intervals, acceleration is uniform (e.g., a freely falling body).

stages.heading: Uniform Speed
stages.content: For an object moving with uniform speed, the distance-time graph is a straight line. The slope of the line indicates the speed.

stages.heading: Non-Uniform Speed
stages.content: For non-uniform speed, the graph is a curved line, showing non-linear variation of distance with time.

stages.heading: Uniform Motion
stages.content: If an object moves at uniform velocity, the graph is a straight line parallel to the time axis. The area under the graph gives the displacement.

stages.heading: Uniform Acceleration
stages.content: For uniformly accelerated motion, the velocity-time graph is a straight line. The area under the graph gives the distance travelled.

stages.heading: The Three Equations
stages.content: For an object moving along a straight line with uniform acceleration: 1) v = u + at (Velocity-time relation), 2) s = ut + ½at² (Position-time relation), 3) 2as = v² - u² (Position-velocity relation).

stages.heading: Symbols
stages.content: u = initial velocity, v = final velocity, a = acceleration, t = time, s = distance.

stages.heading: Accelerated Motion
stages.content: When an object moves in a circular path with uniform speed, its direction changes continuously. Therefore, the velocity changes, making it an accelerated motion.

stages.heading: Examples
stages.content: Examples include the motion of the moon around the earth, a satellite in orbit, or a stone tied to a thread and whirled in a circle.

stages.heading: Formula
stages.content: Speed v = (2πr) / t, where r is the radius of the circular path and t is the time taken for one round.
